scenes.location: HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATION AFTERNOON NEXT DAY.
characters: A PUSH SWEEPER, SWEEPING THE CARPET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern high school auditorium. Over the entrance a bann with a "Coca Cola" logo reads: "GRADUATION TODAY 2 PM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A graduation ceremony is in progress. We DOLLY PAST the b faces of teary-eyed graduates until we stop on ENID. At f we only see the top of her mortarboard; as she lifts her  head we see that she's trying desperately not to laugh. She makes eye-contact with REBECCA, another graduate, who also trying to stifle her laughter. The SPEAKER is in an  elaborate wheelchair with severe-looking traction devices

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school is like the training  wheels for the bicycle of real life.   It is a time for young people to  explore different fields of interest  and to hopefully grow from their  experiences.  After all, that which  we learn from our mistakes can be as  valuable as what we learn from our  textbooks, and often we can turn the  negative experiences that are common  to all high-schoolers into positive  steps toward personal growth and  achievement. In coming to terms with  my own personal setback, which I'm  sure you've all heard about, I've  been able to learn a lot about myself.  I've learned for one thing that I  don't need to rely on drugs and  alcohol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and that I'm very lucky-that more  people besides Carrie and myself  weren't hurt in the accident; I've  learned that I'm blessed with  wonderful parents, teachers and above  all the best classmates in the world --  I love each and every one of you  guys!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and I've learned that to get through  life's obstacles you need faith,  hope and, most of all, a sense of  humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trio of TEENAGE GIRLS (one white, one Asian, one black) come running out from the wings and start dancing and rap The audience loves them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more eduCATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for celeBRATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'cause this is the day of our high  school GraduATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've stayed for the durATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Achieved matricuLATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're the newest members of the  general popuLATION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The auditorium door opens and GRADUATES emerge. Enid &amp run away from the crowd, triumphantly holding rolled up  diplomas. They run toward the school playground, nearly  bursting with excitement over their long-awaited release. Enid stops and looks back at the school. She gives it THE FINGER. They sit on a see-saw, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, what a bunch of retards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought Chipmunk-face was never  going to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I liked her better when she  was an alcoholic crack addict! She  gets in one car wreck and all of a  sudden she's Little Miss Perfect and  everybody loves her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's totally sickening. (she unrolls her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see if they gave me the right  diploma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid opens hers. Instead of a diploma, it's an OFFICIAL  LOOKING DOCUMENT with a pink Post-It note on the front pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Oh suck my fucking dick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These assholes are saying that I  have to go to Summer school and take  some stupid art class!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that stupid hippie art  teacher who failed me sophomore year?   I didn't think that just because you  get an "F" that means you have to  take the class over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign reads "Welcome Graduates".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party in progress in the "Gold Room". A band plays TOP-40 "lite" rock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching band) This is so bad, it's almost good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so bad it's gone past good  and back to bad again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP ON ENID, we see the party from her POV: The six seven MOST POPULAR STUDENTS huddle closely together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think, we'll never have to see  any of these creepy faces ever again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless they're in your Summer school  class!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh... don't turn around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MELORRA, an ambitious, incessantly upbeat classmate,  approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you guys! I can't believe  we made it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we graduated high school --  how totally amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you guys doing this  Summer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be in this actor's  workshop, and I'm hoping to start  going on auditions soon. I'm so  excited to finally have some free  time. We have to get together this  summer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, that'll definitely happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spotting better people  to talk to) Well, bye you guys... CONGRATULATIONS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melorra leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when is she an "actress"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, she needs to die immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TODD, a friendly but slightly below-average-looking guy,  approaches from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Rebecca!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So... we finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me? Am I not even here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Enid... (starting over) So... we finally made it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward pause) So... where are you going to college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before Rebecca can  answer) We're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Both of you?... Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have other plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I should have figured that  you two would do something different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to be when you  grow up, Todd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm going to major in Business  Administration and, I think, minor  in Communications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's exactly the kind of thing  we're trying to avoid. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd starts to talk again but Enid has noticed something to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid grabs Rebecca and turns her away from Todd before he can finish his sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, look! Is Stacy Himmler  going out with Rod Harbaugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He better watch out or he'll get  AIDS when he date-rapes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd, forgotten, walks away. The singer wails a sappy, ma ballad. Enid spots DENNIS, the class loser, wandering aro by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, just think, we'll never see  Dennis again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, think about that... that's  actually totally depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The QUALITY CAFE is Enid and Rebecca' s hangout. A 50-ISH MAN with shaved head, and his VAGUELY DIABOLICAL WIFE sit eating lunch. Enid is drawing a picture of them in her  sketchbook when Rebecca arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at these people behind you.   I'm totally convinced they're  Satanists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look at them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA turns and makes eye contact with MR. SATANIST. Sh calmly turns back to face Enid before cracking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, when are we going to start looking  for our apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon... I have to wait and see how  this Summer class goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you sign up yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just picked the one that  sounded the easiest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's so weird that we're finally  out of high school... We've been  waiting for this our whole life! Now  we can get our own apartment and do  anything we want.  It's such a weird  feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it hasn't really hit me yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter JOHN ELLIS, an obnoxious young man with a perpetual smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't Enid and Rebecca,  the little Jewish girl and her Aryan  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, and how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring that tape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts a videotape on the table, just out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never paid me for that tape with  the Indian dance routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tsk! You Jews are so clever with  money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you stupid redneck hick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look, the satanists are leaving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should follow them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SATANISTS walk outside, they open umbrellas, even  though it's a bright, sunny day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally... Oh my God, look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls get up to follow them. Enid grabs the videotape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John) Thanks for the tape - I'll have to  pay you later, I'm broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, "Dude".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under harsh, glaring sunshine, the girls follow a half-bl behind the SATANISTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do if you're a satanist,  anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sacrifice virgins and  stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That lets us off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SATANISTS continue slowly along with Enid & Rebec following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's some weird secret  satanic society that meets at the  Quality Cafe and all of the other  regular customers are in on it except  for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they're slowly poisoning us or  they're planning to brainwash us and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look at this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid points at the mini-mall in front of them. A new  restaurant - we see their banner: "GRAND OPENING. WOWSVIL THE AUTHENTIC 50'S DINER".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Authentic 50's diner"? Since when  were there mini-malls in the 1950's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's so totally pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in a booth looking at menus. It's a less accurate version of "Johnny Rockets". A golden oldie from the 80's plays on the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can forget this great hit from  the 50's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel as though I've stepped into a  time warp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITER approaches. He has an ostentatious 70's-style  perm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out the awesome "fifties" hairdo  on the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, my name is Allen, and I'll be  your waiter this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Al!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we call you "Weird Al"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh heh. Our specials today are pasta  Vasilio, which is a pasta salad with  a light basil vinaigrette--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a popular dish in the 50's,  huh Weird Al?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine so! Also, we have a spinach  tortellini in a ricotta sauce. Both  of those are $6.95... shall I give  you a few minutes to mull it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want an order of onion rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might actually get the pasta  special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pasta special and an order of onion  rings. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you notice all those weird things  on the menu? Like "The Salad  Explosion"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... and instead of "dessert"  it says "Mindbenders."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that even mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid spots an abandoned newspaper, THE FREE WEEKLY, on th adjoining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out the Personals... maybe our  future husbands are trying to contact  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, this paper is so boring. Who  reads all this shit? (flips through it  until she gets to  the Personals) Here we go... (reading) "Windsurfing Doctor, Mensan IQ,  maverick Sagittarius. Let's hit the  clubs, make each other laugh!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, well here's yours... (reading) "Who said all the most eligible  bachelors are taken? Not this one!   Stunning bod, very snugglelicious  ocean sunset dreamer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al returns with their food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you ladies anything else,  or are you all set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later I might be interested in one  of those far-out "mindbenders."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al leaves. Enid goes back to the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! Listen to this one: "Do you  remember me? Airport shuttle, June  7th. You: striking redhead with yellow  dress, pearl necklace, brown shoes.  I was the bookish fellow in the green  cardigan who helped you find your  contact lens. Am I crazy, or did we  have a moment?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that's so pathetic. I bet she  didn't even notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. And he's like psychotically  obsessing over every little detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should call him and pretend to be  the redhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we totally have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid tears out the ad and puts it in her sketchbook. CU of sketchbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca sit with Rebecca's grandmother OOMIE in living room. They eat TV dinners while watching Oomie's  favorite TV SHOW, which we hear but don't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened next, Donna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I told him he'd better take out  his hose and pump me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don-na?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys! My car was out of gas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGH TRACK. Enid leans toward Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Does Oomie really like this show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Isn't it weird? It's her favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls! Shh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca looks through Enid's sketchbook while Enid fiddle with the remote, fast-forwarding through a tape in the VC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what should we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... I just want to see what's on  this tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. John Ellis always puts on  all this sick stuff that I have to  fast-forward past to get to the good  stuff.  There's supposed to be a Don  Knotts movie on here someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of FAST-FORWARDING. Rebecca glances up from the  sketchbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, what is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid stops fast-forwarding. We don't see the screen but w hear weird sounds like BOOTS WALKING THROUGH DEEP MUD. ENID & REBECCA EEEEWWWW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid lurches forward to avert her gaze. She clicks off th VCR, but leaves the TV on. She notices a PHOTO ALBUM on a bookshelf under the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - why do you have this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lent it to me in like tenth grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking all over for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON ALBUM as she leafs through it. We see a picture a FIVE-YEAR-OLD ENID with glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at how cute I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a little hosebag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON PHOTO of ELEVEN-YEAR-OLD ENID & REBECCA at a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that's back when I hated you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember every minute of that party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another page) There's my dad with Joanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can never keep them all straight -  was she the super-bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she was the second wife. The  third one was the super-bitch -  Maxine. (finds a picture) There! Look at her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON PHOTO of MAXINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a fucking monster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something on TV catches Rebecca's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! This is that comedian I  was telling you about! You have to  see this guy -- he's the absolute  worst!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead-pan comedian, JOEY McCOBB, is doing his stand-up  routine in a standard brick-wall comedy venue. He has a  contrived "I'm a weirdo" shtick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because I live with my mother  people think I'm peculiar... so what  if she's been dead for fifteen years!  Hehn hehn... (Peter Lorre laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that's barely even a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I always say, take my life...  please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's supposed to be so weird, how  come he's wearing Nikes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey McCobb, ladies and gentlemen...  Joey McCobb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey McCobb is our God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet! Actually he reminds me of  that one creep you went out with --  you always go for guys with some  lame, fake shtick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about -- who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Larry guy -- what look was he  going for? A gay tennis player from  the forties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca turns the page of Enid's sketchbook to the torn-o personal ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! We forgot to call the loser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which loser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the green cardigan guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca goes to the phone and offers the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I always have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're better at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she dials) I remember when I first started  reading these I thought DWF stood  for "dwarf!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ear up to phone) What does it stand for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, it's his answering machine... (pause) We hear the indistinct traces of a  musical message followed by a faint  BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, it's me - your "striking blonde."  Of course I remember you.  Let's get  together for lunch sometime... How  about Friday at one o'clock?... Why  don't you meet me at my favorite  restaurant, "Wowsville"... It's in  the mall on Century Parkway... I'll  see you there, darling... and be  sure to wear that sexy green  cardigan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Enid hangs up they both start laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A franchise convenience store with a western motif.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH, 19, is taking his apron off as his BOSS, a humorles Greek immigrant, counts out the cash register. Cheerful M plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AH AH AH! What you think you doing?   You still got five minutes left on  you shift!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid (wearing wraparound shades) & Rebecca enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hello there, young employee of  the Sidewinder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I already told you I'm not  going to give you a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you tell me, young man,  about the various flavors of "frozen  yogurt"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll be done in a minute.   Just wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't understand. I  simply wish to know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH! WHAT YOU DOING!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flavors we're featuring this  week, in addition to old favorites  chocolate and vanilla, are Six-Gun  Strawberry, Wild Cherry Round-up,  and Ten Gallon Tangerine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe I care for any of  those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca giggles. A customer, DOUG, enters: a lowly specim with bad hair-cut, mustache, and jail-house tattoos, wear filthy designer jeans and no shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Josh... I need two packs of  smokes. I'm on a double shift  tonight... fuckin' sixteen hours,  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug brings a 40-ouncer to the counter. Josh has two pack of Newports waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, and gimme six of these beef  jerkys too - I'm hungry enough to  chew the crotch out of a rag doll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug pays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I told you: No shirt, no service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he leaves) Fuck you, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Josh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can we talk in a minute? I'm  almost done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid looks at herself in the security mirror. She takes o her hat and messes up her hair. She then takes off her sh and replaces them with her standard horn-rims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging Enid, points  outside) Look at this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside we see Doug practicing with nunchuks and drinking beer. Heavy metal music blares from his car radio. The BO sees this and goes out to yell at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh joins Enid & Rebecca on the other side of counte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy rules!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Doug? He spends more time here  than I do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Josh, will you give us a ride?   Please? Pretty please? It's going to  be super fun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Josh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, there's no way... find  some other poor sucker to abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh is driving, chauffeur-like, with the two girls relax in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you even need a ride? You  could walk there in two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just an excuse for us to spend  time with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Josh, if this guy freaks out,  will you protect us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has every reason to freak out --  this is a totally fucked-up thing to  do to somebody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I think Josh is too mature for  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, look at the way he drives...  he's like an old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Josh, c'mon... MOVE IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their car accelerates. INT. WOWSVILLE DINER - 12:35 PM. The three of them are seated at a corner booth. A song fr any decade other than the 50's PLAYS on the jukebox. A  BUSINESSMAN enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, maybe that's him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still twenty-five minutes early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't there a million places like  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the ultimate. It's like the  Taj Mahal of bad, fake 50's diners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where's "Weird Al"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHH! He's back there. I can see his  hair bobbing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to "make love" to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to tell him you said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEIRD AL approaches with menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So nice to see you again, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Weird Al, there's something my  friend wants to tell you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHUT UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she wants to MMPH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca puts her hand over Enid's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: A PUSH SWEEPER, SWEEPING THE CARPET.
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: OLD WOMAN slowly sweeping. WE FOLLOW HER BACK TO: Enid, Rebecca & Josh. They're eating: ten minutes have passed, it's 12:45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Josh... Becky and I are trying to  figure out what makes you tick.   Tell us about your political beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious. Give us your whole  basic philosophy in a nutshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, look, that's got to be  him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he wearing a green cardigan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly is a cardigan anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUY joins a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not him... Jesus, stop freaking  me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In answer to your question, I suppose  I endorse policies that are opposed  to stupidity and violence and cruelty  in any form...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured something like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They see a somewhat funny-looking guy in his late 30's,  wearing a green cardigan, SEYMOUR, enter. Enid and Rebecc hunch down in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obviously him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour sits down and looks around. Weird Al brings a men ANOTHER ANGLE ON: WEIRD AL bringing his milkshake. Ten mo minutes have passed, it's 12:55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on now? What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, he just ordered a giant  glass of milk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting her bubble) It's a vanilla milkshake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen more minutes have passed - it's 1:10 PM. Seymour  looks around, still hopeful. His date is now TEN MINUTES  LATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still just sitting there. God,  this is totally unbearable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and look, but don't make it  too obvious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca turns around and pretends to look past Seymour. It's now 1:30 PM. His date is 30 MINUTES LATE. Seymour ge up and walks sadly towards the cashier (Weird Al).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch him leave. Enid goes up to pay the bill while  Josh and Rebecca go outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Weird Al, did that guy say  anything to you before he left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid goes back to the table to leave a tip, two dollars. passes behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully  professional despite  her abuse) Thank you and come again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid hesitates, overcome with guilt. She glances back at then digs every penny out of her pocket (about seven doll in coins and wadded up bills) and adds it to his tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trio drive in silence. Suddenly, an extra-wide pick-u vrooms past Josh, cutting off the driver (SEYMOUR) next t him. SEYMOUR bobs violently as he screams silent obscenit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, that's HIM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally! Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: SEYMOUR really having a fit now. Once it's out his system, he reverts to an amiable poker-face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should follow him home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Josh... don't you want to  see where he lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this guy is like a one-of-kind,  rare butterfly, and we have to follow  him back to his natural habitat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need counseling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several minutes have passed. Seymour parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he lives right in our  neighborhood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour gets out and disappears up the steps of his build

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't even look that bummed  out, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... wouldn't you be totally  pissed off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kind of thing must happen to  him all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SCREEN: grainy B&W video footage. The CAMERA tra a shadowy flight of stairs. We hear FOOTSTEPS, a rhythmic POUNDING, and a deranged CHILDREN'S CHOIR ("LALALALALALA"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheap echo effect) Returning to the house of my  Fatherfatherfatherfather...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA reaches the top of the stairs, we see a door t slowly CREAKS open. We move into the room beyond, it's  decorated with stuff from the 50's and a giant crucifix. HEAR a televangelist's sermon. We MOVE CLOSE on a little  girl's doll. Very slowly a MAN'S HAND reaches for the dol and drags it into the shadows. The hand throws the now  mutilated doll into a toilet; water and blood swirl aroun We see grainy footage (shot off of TV) of Christians angr picketing an abortion clinic. CREDITS come up: THE END. FILM BY ROBERTA ALLSWORTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go on, the VIDEO ends and the monitor is shut  off. There are about a dozen students, mostly pimply 14-year-o boys, a few 14-ish girls, and Enid, dressed in schoolgirl outfit. The teacher, ROBERTA ALLSWORTH, addresses the cla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That piece is entitled  "Mirror/Father/Mirror." I like to  show it to people I'm meeting for  the first time because it says so  much about who I am and what it feels  like to inhabit my specific skin.   And this is exactly what I'm hoping  to get from each of you over the  course of this Summer: a picture of  your own self-exploration. My own  background is in video and performance  art, but I'm hoping that doesn't  influence you and that you'll find  your own ways of externalizing the  internal. At the end of the Summer,  this class has been invited, along  with several others in the area, to  participate in a show of High-School  art at the Neighborhood Activity  Center. The title of the show will  be "Brotherhood and Community: Art  as Dialogue." I think the  "Brotherhood" theme ties in nicely  with the theme of self-discovery  that I'd like to emphasize in this  class. Are there any questions so  far? (she's completely  lost them) Great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca stand in front of Seymour's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is way too creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't see us... we'll just stalk  him from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid if I see him, I'll start  feeling really bad again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what should we do? We can't just  hide all day waiting for him to come  out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three mail slots. Enid pulls the mail out of th first one. We see FLOWER BULB CATALOGUES, and LADIES HOME JOURNAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is girl mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs the mail out of SLOT NUMBER TWO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all computer catalogues and  stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is looking at the mail from SLOT NUMBER THREE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The W.C. Fields Fan Club Newsletter... (she flips through  the mail) Oh my God, The National Psoriasis  Foundation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves back the contents of slot number two and grabs the mail from Rebecca. We hear MALE VOICES around the cor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Do you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid jams the mail back in the slot in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They slowly walk around the bushes toward the voices. INT. SEYMOUR & JOE'S GARAGE SALE - DAY They see the GARAGE SALE, in progress. They've all spotte each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should we do? What if he  recognizes us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's too late now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged HOUSEWIFE browses with little enthusiasm as Enid & Rebecca tentatively approach. Enid spots a MON VS. COBRA taxidermy piece near Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ew, look at this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's cute - look at his little  weasel teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ew, it's like some gross rat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hardly looking up  from TV) It's a mongoose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mongoose... they eat snakes... you  never heard of a mongoose?  That's a  classic piece of vintage taxidermy.  Nobody alive today knows how to do  work like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking underneath  it) How much is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm... That's not officially for  sale... I might have to hang onto  that for the time being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shuts off the TV. He turns to the girls, not wanting lose the rapport he's established with two potential  customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, are you looking for anything in  particular? There's a lot of other  stuff in storage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a plastic Casio-type guitar/keyboard (a child toy) and starts noodling pre-programmed rock licks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the "Jam-in-ator" appeals to  you.  Absolutely no practice  necessary.  You shread like a giant.  Just press a button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices several modern jazz LPs on Joe's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any other old records  besides these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him. Seymour. He's the man with the  records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid glances at Rebecca and mouths the implausible name:  "Seymour?!" Rebecca snorts, unable to control her laughte and turns away from the table. Enid keeps her cool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any old Indian records?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian records?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, like weird 1960's Indian  rock n' roll music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have anything after about  1935. I may have one Hindu 78 from  the twenties in my collection, but  it's not really for sale. I don't  really collect "foreign."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid drifts over and begins thumbing through a box of 78s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are all 78s... Can you play  78s?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!... Wait, maybe not 78s, but I  can play regular records...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points her to a nearby box of LPs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some good stuff in here...  do you like old music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there's a few choice LPs in  here that re-issue some really great  old blues stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca tugs on Enid's sleeve. Enid gets free and continu looking through the records. She stops on one with an  especially wacky cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this one any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, it's not so great. Here's the  one I'd recommend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out a bland-looking record: "COLLECTOR'S ITEMS,  VOLUME THREE." Rebecca shifts impatiently behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This track alone by Memphis Minnie  is worth about $500 if you have the  original 78. She was one of the  greatest guitar players that ever  lived, and a great singer and  songwriter as well. I know the guy  who owns the original and lent it  for use on this reissue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca snorts at Enid's over-exuberance. Enid kicks her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dollar seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pays him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't like it bring it back  for a refund. We're here every  Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the record into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Rebecca sit in their usual booth. Rebecca is r THE FREE WEEKLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was truly pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... I still can't get over  that his name was "Seymour."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca starts looking through the APARTMENT LISTINGS. Sh takes a pen out of her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was so excited when you bought  that record -- you're a saint!...   God, these apartments are super  expensive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so cute how he had his own  little bags. I thought I was going  to start crying!... Do you think  they're gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the "striking redhead in  the yellow dress"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should totally just kill himself...  Hey, here's one (circles it) ...Oh wait... (crosses it out) you have to share it with a non  smoking feminist and her two cats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I kind of like him...   He's the exact opposite of everything  I really hate... In a way he's such  a clueless dork that he's almost  cool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy is many things but he  definitely isn't "cool"... This one  would be okay, but there's no  kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but... you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, I can't explain it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward silence. Melorra enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, what are you guys doing  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Melorra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My acting workshop is across the  street from here. I'm just on my  break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we won't keep you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this place... it's so - you  know, "funky."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God how cool. Where are you moving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sure yet, that's why we're  looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God that's so exciting! (looks at clock) Oops, I should go. Bye you guys!   Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melorra leaves quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Funky"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, is she black now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch her cross the street - she's dressed in expens "casual" clothes with a fancy backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about when we  look for our apartment how we have  to try and convince people that we're  like these totally rich yuppies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's who people want to rent to.   It's a known fact that it's way easier  to get a job and everything if you're  rich... All we have to do is buy a  few semi-expensive outfits and act  like it's no big deal... it'll be  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just want an excuse to dress  like some stupid fashion model without  me making fun of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just promise you'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, I promise... Jesus, you're  out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud water running; PUNK ROCK blares from adjoining bedro as Enid, her head in the sink, sings along, making up her own words. As she straightens INTO FRAME, we see that she dyed her hair green. She grabs a towel and heads into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her DAD enters with a mixing bowl, oblivious to the green hair and loud music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over music) Have you seen my blue spatula?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. What are you making, pancakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I don't find that goddamn  spatula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad leaves. Enid messes up her hair in different ways whi singing along to the tape and looking at herself in the  mirror. Rebecca opens the door and stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainful) When did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid turns around, startled, but instantly regains helps  composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? How long have you been standing  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have to buy new hair dye or  did you still have some left over  from eighth grade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk past a sad-looking ACME SHOES AND REPAIR STORE, a distinctive old building, that looks as if it's been th forever. They stop and peer through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still have to go in there sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always closed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet they have tons of incredible  shoes hidden in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look, it's the pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a pair of discarded jeans on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go hassle Josh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hassle"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They see a MIDDLE-AGED MAN dressed in a shabby threadbare suit and hat sitting at what was once a bus stop. The rus sign has a red sticker on it that says "No longer in serv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for the bus that never  comes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if he's just totally insane  and he really thinks a bus is coming  or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid sits next to THE MAN. Rebecca stands behind the benc taken aback that Enid is going to end the long standing  speculation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at watchless  wrist, then down the  street) Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...are you waiting for a bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to tell you this but they  cancelled this bus line two years  ago... There are no buses on this  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Rebecca are on the outside porch/walkway on th floor of Josh's building. Enid POUNDS on his pasteboard d the windows RATTLE with each hollow THUD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH! ENID & REBECCA JOSH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably in there jerking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he never jerks off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's beyond human stuff like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we leave a note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid finds a piece of paper - the back of a pizza flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a pen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She writes, while Rebecca looks over her shoulder. "Dear  Josh. We came by to fuck you but you didn't answer the do Therefore you are gay. Signed, Tiffany and Amber."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not really going to leave  that are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid pushes the note over his doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we going here? I hate this  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll only take a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. We see racks of books-with titles like "Make  Explosives At Home." Rebecca walks over to the magazine r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm telling you, you're wrong --  carpet beetles are the only way to  get the flesh off a corpse...  Boiling  is strictly for amateurs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you creeps ever talk about  anything nice? Don't you ever talk  about fluffy kittens or the Easter  Bunny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's talking - little miss  badass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, nice outfit - who are you  supposed to be, Cyndi Lauper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow me, doofus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Ellis emerges from the back and begins to unload a b of books onto the shelves. He stops and looks at Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't they tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punk rock is over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's over, asshole, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you really want to "fuck up the  system" - you should go to business  school -- that's what I'm gonna do:  get a job at some big corporation  and fuck things up from the inside!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not even --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah. Do you have my money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wads up a twenty-dollar bill and throws it at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, how "punk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tape sucked, by the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry if you were offended!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads toward the back room with the empty box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go die, asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Rebecca walks over to Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like I'm some modern Punk  dickhead... It's obviously supposed  to be a 1977 Punk look, but I guess  Johnny Fuckface is too stupid to get  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's too stupid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid dejectedly enters and heads straight for the bathroo She rummages through a cabinet until she finds the right (black hair dye). She wets her hair, then goes into the  bedroom and mechanically turns on her boom box. The punk  rock song we heard earlier plays. She yanks out the tape flings it away. She skims through her records and CDs,  dismissing them all. She notices Seymour's bag in the cor She takes out the record and puts it on. The first tune i an upbeat instrumental number. She returns to the bathroo Several minutes pass. TRACK TWO begins on the LP. She (an we) slowly begin to take notice. It's a strange, haunting old BLUES RECORD. We see that the tune has struck a nerve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song continues. Enid sits in her bean-bag chair. Her  hair is now dyed back to black. As the song ends, she pic up the needle and starts it again. INT. SEYMOUR & JOE'S GARAGE SALE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it took a while before I got a  chance to play it, but when I heard  that song it was like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you really liked it? Yeah, there's  some really rare performances. You  liked that Memphis Minnie, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's good too... the whole  record was good, but that one song,  "Devil Got My Woman" -- I mostly  just keep playing that one over and  over... Do you have any other records  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Skip James record? Yeah, that's  a masterpiece. There are no other  records like that! I actually have  the original 78 of it in my  collection. It's one of maybe five  known copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nearly sincere) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see it? I can run  upstairs and get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe, he always  says this when he  leaves his table) Watch my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour exits. An uncomfortable pause as Enid stands at t table. She touches the mongoose's tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) You still interested in that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it wasn't for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinkin' maybe I could let it  go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour returns with the 78, holding it like a precious  object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is. It's only about V minus  and has an incipient lam crack, but  plays decent as I recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour passes the 78 to Enid who follows suit and holds carefully by the edges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid pretends to drop the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops! I dropped it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I was only kidding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the record back to Seymour, who's shaken and  embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Seymour... are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starts with a PAN ACROSS a wall of unimpressive high scho art: dumb drawings of fighting Chuck Norris-types, traced centerfolds, highly sexualized horses, etc. And, on a tab a wire sculpture made from two coathangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to start a discourse  on the subject of "good" art vs.  "bad" art; these judgments are for  each person to make on his own. I  merely want to help each of you find  the best way to look within yourselves  the best key to your particular lock.  Last week I asked you to-try and  create a piece of artwork that  responds to something that you have  strong feelings about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid enters late and puts her sketchbook on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it looks like we have some really  interesting work up here....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta peruses some of the art, then points to a very vi drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you tell, us about your  piece... uh... (struggles to read  signature) ...Phillip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very stupid and  nervous) Uh... it's uh... it's about The  Mutilator...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's this really great video game  about a guy who kills people with a  big hammer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make a  joke) I thought maybe this was supposed to  be your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response from Phillip. Roberta nicks up Enid's sketchb and leafs through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what can you tell us about this... (searches for name)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid. It's sort of like a diary I  guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see several sketches, including the drawing of the  SATANISTS. Roberta shows a few pages to the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that Phillip and Enid can  help us to see that there are-many  different ways we can express  ourselves.  We can do things like  these cartoons that are amusing as a  sort of light entertainment or we  can do work that is more serious in  scope and feeling and that deals  with issues; emotional, spiritual,  political; of great importance. I  hope that you will each have the  tools to do that type of work by the  end of this class. (pause, points at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is responsible for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to us about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my response to the issue of a  woman's right to choose... it's  something I feel super-strongly about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this a wonderful piece, class?  This definitely falls into that higher  category of art I was speaking of  earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET glances over at Enid. Enid gives her a dirty loo INT. "MASTERPIECE VIDEO" STORE - AFTERNOON. On a monitor, a generic trailer is playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello and welcome to Masterpiece  video. How may I help you this  afternoon, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a copy of 8 1/2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir! Is it a new release, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's the classic Italian film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me look that up on the computer  for you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, here it is - 9 1/2 WEEKS with  Mickey Rourke. It's in our "Erotic  Dramas" section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not "9 1/2", 8 1/2 , the Fellini  film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check that for you sir. How do  you spell the actor's name - F-I-L-E- E-P-E-E...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE Enid & Rebecca, dressed up in sexy outfits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you have to see my new good  luck charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out a small porcelain figure of a MAN FLUSHING  HIMSELF DOWN A TOILET with the words "Goodbye Cruel World on the base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ew ... when did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning at Seymour's garage  sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, aren't you tired of Seymour  yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca picks up another tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I'm sure it sucks. All  these movies suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An obnoxious SIX-YEAR-OLD tries to get his PARENTS to add another tape to their already tall stack. He stares at th video monitor. Another MASTERPIECE EMPLOYEE reshelves videos near them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overly cheerful) Hello! How are you young ladies this  evening? May I help you find a  particular Masterpiece movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here, this place  makes me sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to do something fun tonight  this is my last weekend of freedom  before I start my stupid job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a party we could go to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Where?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I promise you there's really a  party with a lot of guys, do you  promise you'll go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. SEYMOUR & JOE'S LIVING ROOM - EVENING A depressing COLLECTORS' GET-TOGETHER in progress. Enid & Rebecca sit on an old sofa in the corner. Nine or ten REC COLLECTORS mill about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some records I will pay  serious money for, provided they're  a sincere V plus. Other than that  I'd prefer to just have them on CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CDs will never have the presence of  an original 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRR-ONG! A digital transfer adequately  mastered will sound identical to the  original. Do you have a decent  equalizer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a Klipsch 2B3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously the problem! You expect a  ten-band equalizer to impart state  of-the-art sound? Dream a little  dream! etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Rebecca are sitting nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I totally, totally hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw c'mon, this is a fun party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: Joe stands talking to GERROLD, an obnoxious, pu fast-talking guy who keeps eyeing Rebecca. He shovels foo into his mouth as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the story with the two  cheerleaders over here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're Seymour's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour? You gotta be kidding me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. He's not gettin'  any and neither are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (poking Joe in the  chest) Let me tell ya somethin', Joe...   Listen to me, Joe... you can't hit a  home run without swinging the bat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gerrold walks over to where Rebecca is sitting. He sits o the arm of sofa next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring straight  ahead) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, that was cold! Hey, you're  okay, you're pretty sharp. So uh...  hey, you're wearing a green dress -  whadda you Irish? I bet you're Irish.  What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melorra...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melorra, listen to me - let me tell  you something Melorra... you seem  like an interesting chick - what are  you doing hanging out with these  losers here? Whaddya say you and me  take off and hit some nightspots  etc. etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back, I'm gonna go get  a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ENID) Wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid goes over to the beer keg. Nearby Seymour stands tal to PAUL - a humorless, middle-aged guy in a suit and tie  who's contemptuously examining one of Seymour's 78s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but it plays like new. There's no  groove wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please... It has an enlarged center  hole and a hair crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the crack is so tight it's  completely inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tight hair crack is just that - a  crack. I don't collect cracked  records. (walking away) I only pay a premium for mint records  Seymour, you know that!  Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was all that stuff about enlarged  holes and tight cracks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I didn't think you would have  any interest in this get together...  I mean if you had told me you were  coming I would have warned you --  it's not like a real party or  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right about that. (pause) So this is your record collection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God no. This is just junk I have  for sale or trade. The record room  is off-limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Can I see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well sure... you can if you  want to... it's just I don't want  all these guys in there at once...  you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Seymour enter his inner sanctum, beverage cont in hand -- nicely-displayed old collectibles cover just a every inch of wall space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! This is like my dream room!   Are these all records!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have about fifteen hundred 78s at  this point. I've tried to pare down  my collection to the essential...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, look at this poster!  I can't  believe this room! You're the luckiest  guy in the world! I'd kill to have  stuff like this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... go ahead and kill me!   This stuff doesn't make you happy,  believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on! What are you talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's healthy to obsessively  collect things? You can't connect  with other people so you fill your  life with stuff...  I'm just like  all the rest of these pathetic  collector losers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid writes her name in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not! You're a cool guy,  Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right... If I'm so cool, why  haven't I had a girlfriend in four  years? I can't even remember the  last time a girl talked to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to you... I'll bet there  are tons of women who would go out  with you in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No really... I guarantee I could get  you a date in like two seconds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm totally serious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it -- You leave everything to  me -- I'm going to be your own  personal dating service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate the offer but you really  don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark my words, by the end of this  summer you'll be up to your neck in  pussy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus! That's very nice of you Enid  but I - I really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Enid and Seymour walk. A 20-ish secretary-type passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her? Would you go out  with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, what kind of question  is that? I mean it's totally  irrelevant because a girl like that  would never be caught dead with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But putting that aside for now, would  you go out with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really didn't get a good look at  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breasty, overweight 40-year-old walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what about this one? Are you  into girls with big tits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Seymour, I'm trying to collect  data here! Don't you want me to find  you your perfect dream girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not one of those guys who  has a "type"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every guy has a type!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he doesn't really  mean this) I mean as long as she's not a complete  imbecile and she's even remotely  attractive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk by "the pants."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look, there's Norman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting as before at the defunct bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman nods politely. Seymour looks quizzically at Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in another part of town near THE SIDEWINDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to narrow this down somehow...  we need to find a place where you  can meet women who share your  interests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't want to meet someone  who shares my interests.  I hate my  interests! Where can I go to meet  the exact opposite of myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah... Just tell me your  five main interests, in order of  importance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well, let's see... I guess I'd have  to put Traditional Jazz, Blues, and  Ragtime music at the top of the list,  then probably...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say "music" - that way  you only use up one... (spots The Sidewinder) Wait, we have to go in here for a  second...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Josh has his back to the counter as he makes complicated frozen yogurt sundae for a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Josh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning around) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just stopped in to say hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around non-chalantly, holding the sundae. He loo up and sees Enid with the guy from Wowsville (Seymour).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my friend Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh is startled and drops the sundae. The girl starts cr Josh immediately starts to clean up the mess. Enid, satis heads with Seymour for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, Josh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door closes, we hear a familiar voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH! WHAT YOU DOING!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Seymour continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So is that your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh? He's nobody's boyfriend...   He's just this guy that Becky and I  like to torture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts suddenly) Oh my god! We have to go in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in front of STAN'S, a porno shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... very funny....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Seymour... Becky and I have  been dying to go in here but we can't  get any boys to take us...  Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I'd really rather not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just go in for one minute --  it'll be a riot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLEASE? We have to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't think it's a good  idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, I'll go by myself then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Seymour enter. There are a half dozen MEN brow through the videos and magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Wow! Look at all these creeps!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OH MY GOD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid runs over and grabs a BLOW-UP SEX DOLL. Everyone in store looks at them. Seymour blushes and sweats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of weirdo would actually  have sex with this? We have to buy  this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around, over-stimulated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, this place is a total riot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this -- "Lollipop Lolitas" -  isn't child pornography totally  illegal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are older women just dressed  up to look young... I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON a pair of THIGH-HIGH LEATHER FETISH BOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER ANGLE: She's in another part of the store near the  CASHIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are these boots? Do you  have these in size five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the only pair of those I have  right now. I'm getting a new order  in next week...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spots something and gasps. She yells across the store

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OH MY GOD SEYMOUR! You have to lend  me the money to buy this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at Seymour as he sheepishly approaches. He takes out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I don't have much money with me  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Seymour, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come back in two weeks -  we'll be having our annual Back-to- School sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is at the counter serving a long line of YUPPIES. can see a sign next to the counter that reads: "Answer to trivia question and get a free small coffee".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like a medium latte for here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you a biscotti to go with  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! Just the latte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is next wearing a RUBBER BONDAGE MASK with devil hor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me all your money, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't believe it! Guess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony's II!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way... when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now... I went with Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cunt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FELDMAN is in line behind Enid. He's a poodle-haired, fed wearing eccentric in a motorized wheelchair-golf cart  contraption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me - I can't read the trivia  question!
