dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is in the way. She reads it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where on the human body is the  'Douglas Pouch' located?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feldman grunts and starts to tap away on his powerbook wh Rebecca, rolling her eyes, goes to get his coffee. A DIGI GRAPHIC of the FEMALE FORM on his computer screen. With a few keyboard strokes he zeroes in on a schematic of the  REPRODUCTIVE SYSTEM. An area behind the cervix BLINKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slightly below the uterus on a female.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his coffee and putters towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy is totally amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does that every single day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get a decaf mocha to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO, I don't want a biscotti with  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YUPPIE #2 pays and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, how can you stand all these  assholes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Some people are okay,  but mostly I feel like poisoning  everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least the wheelchair guy is sort  of entertaining...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a total asshole... He doesn't  even need that wheelchair, he's just  totally lazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That rules!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't. You'll see... you  get totally sick of all the creeps  and losers and weirdos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But those are our people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... (pause) So when are you going to get your  job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working on it... I've got a few  leads... it's just that right now I  have, all these projects that take  up all my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Don't worry... I promise  I'll get a job next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) God, I can't believe you went to  Anthony's without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid and her dad are eating breakfast. A 13" TV sits on t kitchen counter behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincere) Hope comes in all forms. To the  endangered white stork searching for  wetlands it comes in the form of a  sanctuary provided by people who  care. Do people care? Chevron does.  That's why at Chevron we're just as  concerned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still looking for a job? Do  you have any leads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get off my back for once?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tough to find a good job without  any kind of training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I told you I'm not going to  college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think it's good to keep all  your options open. You can always  enroll for the winter quarter.  You  could even live here and go to the  city college part time, and still  get a job if you wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me -- I'm not even listening  to a word you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I tell you who I ran into at the  bagel place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading cereal box) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone from the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the Maxine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, how horrifying.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLLEGE COFFEE HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Enid and Rebecca sit in a semi-crowded college hang-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you don't have to make a million  dollars -- just get any stupid job  so we can at least start looking for  an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful pause) I wonder if I hang around with you  because you're like my surrogate  mother figure or something. Like I  have this subconscious biological  need to be nagged and bitched at  constantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hang out with me because nobody  else can stand to be around you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe... did you ever think that  deep down we really might be lesbos?  Maybe that's why we spend so much  time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gross. (pause) See that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives me a total boner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's like the biggest idiot of all  time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy, a COLLEGE SOPHOMORE, walks by them with two frie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you guys up for some reggae  tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Heads up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An earnest "ALTERNATIVE-ROCK" GUY approaches Rebecca. He  hands her a flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my band is playing here on Friday  night and uh... there's gonna be a  bunch of cool bands playing and stuff  and you don't have to pay if you  show this flyer at the door... you  should come check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Thanks... (she looks away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid takes the flyer from Rebecca.  There are a bunch of  bands listed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is your band?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alien Autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Bitchin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassing pause;  then, to Rebecca) Yeah, well... maybe I'll see you  there... (pause; walks away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a dork!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right... Believe me, at this  point I'm over the fact that every  single guy likes you better than me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it, you hate every single boy  on the face of the earth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true, I just hate all  these obnoxious, extroverted, pseudo- bohemian losers! (sad pause) Sometimes I think I act so weird  because I'm crazy from sexual  frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you heard about the miracle  of masturbation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) ...maybe we should be lesbos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starts on full moon in night sky, framed right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a dark moonlit room. Enid lies on her stomach in bed. MOVE IN CLOSER to her head as though entering her thought which slowly fade in: WE MOVE TOWARD a vertical sliver of light -- a cracked-open bathroom door. WE MOVE into the bathroom and see Enid taking a shower. J enters, dressed in a black suit, holding a large bouquet flowers. CUT. We start again, exactly as before, only wit the flowers. He starts to take off his clothes. CUT. He e again and gets right in the shower, fully clothed. They begin to kiss. After a passionate moment, the door o Rebecca stands there, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: We see only the slightest trace of Enid in the darkness. sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP ON a charcoal portrait of DON KNOTTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this, Enid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be Don Knotts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was your reason for choosing  him as your subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I just like Don Knotts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see... interesting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we have here, Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tampon in a teacup...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class GIGGLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that... now what can you  tell us about it? First of all, what  kind of sculpture is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a "found object"... that's when  an artist takes an ordinary object  and places it in an artistic context  and thus it becomes art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Now, what can you tell us  about it in regard to your artistic  intent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I see the teacup as a symbol  for womanhood, because of tea parties  in the olden days, but instead of  tea I was trying to kind of confront  people with this... like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shocking image of repressed  femininity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, exactly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's really a wonderful piece,  Margaret!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid gives Margaret another dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This illustrates perfectly what I  was saying about not being afraid to  use controversial imagery, class...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour drives. Enid plays with the radio stopping on an  obnoxious AM Disc Jockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KFTO comin' atchya on this beautiful  evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that asshole's voice is so  hateful! No wonder I never listen to  the radio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shutting it off) Relax, Seymour, relax...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thing is just so shrill and  piercing and loud - it's like someone  jabbing me in the face! (imitating insincere  DJ voice) KFTO comin' atchya on this beautiful  evening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She changes the subject and holds up a 78 record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, why did you bring this along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought it for him to autograph.   He's going to be amazed to see it -  it's one of two known copies... I  can't believe they have him for the  opening act and not the headliner.   What an insult!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bar's going to be packed with  girls for you to pick from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not holding my breath in that  department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour waits at a stop sign for two OBLIVIOUS OVERWEIGHT WOMEN, each with TODDLERS and baby carriages, to cross..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we, in slow motion here?!   What are ya, hypnotized? Have some  more kids, why don't you?... For  Christ's sake, would you move!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A marquee reads, "TONITE: BLUESHAMMER also FRED CHATMAN"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED CHATMAN, age 82, plays an acoustic blues number. He' good, but he's being politely ignored for the most part b the TWENTY-SOMETHING PATRONS. Most of them are more inter in a baseball game showing on a big-screen TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe these people! They  could at least turn off their stupid  sports game until he's done playing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED finishes to POLITE APPLAUSE. An M.C. takes the mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it for Fred Chatman. (a little more APPLAUSE) Hey don't go away because we've got  Blueshammer coming up in just a  minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CUTE GIRL, mid-20's, stands near their table sipping he drink. Enid nods in her direction for Seymour's benefit a if to say, "check it out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that would certainly do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, offer her a seat! You want me  to do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Hang on! Jesus, I  gotta think of something to talk to  her about. No! No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid gets up before Seymour can stop her and talks to CUT GIRL who looks back at Seymour and smiles. She goes to jo him. Enid walks off in the direction of the bar, giving  Seymour a "thumbs up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Uh... that was great music,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting down) Yeah, I just love blues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, technically what he was  mostly playing would more accurately  be classified in the "ragtime" idiom.  Although of course not in the  strictest sense of the more classical  ragtime piano music like that of  Scott Joplin or Joseph Lamb. Authentic  Blues has a more conventional twelve- bar structure in its stanzas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh if you like authentic blues, you've  just gotta see Blueshammer!  They're  so great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: Enid standing alone at the bar. We see Seymour Cute Girl from her POV. Her gaze drifts to the other peop in the bar. WE MOVE OVER the faces of all the guys and st on a skinny, introverted-looking guy with a pool-cue. He  makes a shot and instantly goes into an ostentatious cue  twirling routine. Her gaze drifts on. She sees herself in a mirror behind the bar and takes off her hat reconfiguring her hair. She reaches into her purs and puts on a bulkier pair of glasses. This is interrupte by BLUESHAMMER taking the stage. Young, white, cocky, pre boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right people! Are you ready to  BOOGIE? Cuz we gwine play you some  authentic, way-down-in-the-delta  blues to rock your world! One, Two,  Three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A din of loud noise. CUTE GIRL immediately leaps to her f boogeying to the music. Several horny ALPHA MALES press in on Seymour (who's stil sitting), spilling his drink as they vie to dance with he Seymour extricates himself from the table and walks towar the bar where Enid sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her you were a big record  executive and you were thinking of  signing that band to your label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I remember why I haven't gone  anywhere in months. I'm not even in  the same universe as those creatures  back there. I might as well be from  another planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just need to figure out a place  where you can meet somebody who isn't  a total idiot, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I really appreciate your help,  Enid, but let's face it, this is  hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not hopeless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well it's simple for everybody  else - give 'em a Big Mac and a pair  of Nikes and they're happy! I just  can't relate to 99.9% of humanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I can't relate to humanity  either, but I don't think it's totally  hopeless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not totally hopeless for  you... I've had it. I don't even  have the energy to try anymore.  You  should make sure you do the exact  opposite of everything I do so you  don't end up like me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather end up like you than those  people at that stupid bar...  At  least you're an interesting person...  at least you're not exactly like  everybody else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooray for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid walks in behind Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I have anything to  drink... there might be some --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter, I'm not staying  long... I just want to make sure I  convince you not to give up yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yet."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both have drinks now. He puts on a jazz record, an  instrumental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up an antique  knick knack) Wow, this is so cool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my asking -- why  do you care so much if I get a date  or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... because I can't stand the  idea of a world where a guy like you  can't get a date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid finds a PAINTING leaning in a pile of stuff against wall in the corner. It's an old-fashioned cartoony stereo of a black man's head, with big lips and a huge toothy sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck, Seymour?! What is  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Oh that... I borrowed that  from work about fifteen years ago...  I guess it's mine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are you a klansman or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right, I'm a klansman - thanks  a lot!... Do you know the Cook's  Chicken franchise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting TV commercial  in deep voice) "Four-piece Cook's special deep fried  with side n' slaw it's OUT RAY-GEOUS"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well "Cook's" is just a made  up name. When they originally opened  back in 1922 they were named "The  Coon Chicken Inn" -- that's an early  painting of their first logo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a scrapbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm obsessed with all this stuff -  this lost culture of the 20th century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks through the scrapbook - we see the Coon Chicken logo transform first into a less stereotyped black man, t into an older distinguished black chef with the logo "Coo Chicken Inn." Then to a white version of the same chef,  followed by a female white chef, then to a streamlined 90 version. On another page is a collection of cosmetic labe tracing the design evolution of a different company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't everybody know this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record ends. Seymour gets up to take it off the turnt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat bitterly) It's ancient history. The same reason  nobody knows about this Lionel Belasco  record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on another record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I was a whole lot more  interested in the Cook's phenomenon  when I was about your age. I've kind  of lost interest since I've been  working for them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work at Cook's Chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For nineteen years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, a fry cook or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing so glamorous... actually,  I'm an assistant manager at their  corporate headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'd go nuts if I had to work  in an office all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I get good benefits, a good  early retirement plan, nobody ever  bothers me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but still...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make enough money to eat and buy  old records... what more do I want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid puts down the scrapbook, stares at the painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I don't really get it -- are you  saying that things were better back  then (points at painting) even though there was stuff like  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, in a lot of ways things are better  now... I dunno... it's complicated.  Everybody still hates each other,  but they know how to hide it better,  or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Hey, can I borrow this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise I'll take good care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... they're very sensitive at  work about all this stuff. Maybe it  would be better if you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you trust me, Seymour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see another wall of student art dominated this time by Enid's (Seymour's) 3' x 4' painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's address some discussion to  this piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's totally weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's not right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More kids respond at once. Even Margaret is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all valid comments, but I  think we should see if the artist  has anything to bring to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got the idea when I was doing  some research and I discovered that  Cook's Chicken used to be called  Coon's Chicken, and so I decided to  do my project based on this discovery  as kind of a comment on racism...  and the way racism is whitewashed  over in our culture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you actually do this painting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no - it's more like a "found  art object."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you think this addresses  the subject of racism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's complicated... I guess I'm trying  to show how racism used to -- more  out in the open and now it's hidden,  or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how does an image like this help  us to see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure... I mean... (thinks) I guess because when we see something  like this it seems really shocking  and we have to figure out why it's  so shocking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause as Roberta and the class stare at the painti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know what to say,  Enid... (another over-long  pause) ...It's a remarkable achievement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is lying on her back with her head on Rebecca's stom Both stare blankly at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? It's a dream job!   I can't believe you got a job like  that without even trying... God, I  wish that was my job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to generate  some enthusiasm) Yeah, maybe it'll be okay. At least  I'll get to see every movie for free,  I guess... I had to lie and tell  them I already graduated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you finally going to get  your diploma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, but next week is my last  class...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, now we can start looking for  the apartment... (waits for some  response from Enid,  but there is none) Do you remember when we first came  up with that whole idea of renting  our own apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it like eighth grade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventh... you wanted to move out  right then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been when my dad was  married to Maxine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember our big plan was as soon  as we got the apartment we were going  to trick Daniel Dusentrieb into coming  over and then fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were such desperate sluts back  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is behind the candy counter dressed in a brown and o uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna let you handle the four  thirty crowd by yourself - that way  I can evaluate your performance while  it's slow and ease you into the bigger  crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can count on me, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A customer, an ALCOHOLIC LOSER, approaches the candy coun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you serve beer or any alcohol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish!... actually you wish... after  about five minutes of this movie  you'll wish to God you had about ten  beers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOSER stares blankly, hesitates, then goes into theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her aside) What are you doing? You don't ever  criticize the feature!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What difference does it make?   You already got his money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that's the policy... if you  want to make up your own rules you  can open your own theater...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I was only trying to be  friendly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we don't pay you to be a movie  critic -- just do your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... I won't say a word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE - an hour has gone by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medium popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's three dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have plenty of butter on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewww!... (making a face) Here you go -- smothered in delicious  yellow-chemical sludge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her aside) What the hell is wrong with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm just kidding around with  the customers... It's my shtick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well lose it! And why aren't you  pushing the large sizes? Didn't you  get training about upsizing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I feel weird... it's so sleazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not optional!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get a medium sprite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medium sprite? Why sir, do you not  know that for a mere twenty five  cents more you could purchase a large  beverage that has a volume of over  twice that of a puny medium drink? (she gives MANAGER a  look) ...I'm only telling you this because  we're such good friends -- Medium is  strictly for suckers who don't  understand the concept of value!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is behind the counter glaring at Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? What  kind of loser gets fired after one  day?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you - my manager was a total  asshole! Don't worry, I'm going to  get another job... and anyway, I  have some ideas for how to make money  in the meantime...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angry CUSTOMER returns with her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not at all happy with this latte  what do you intend to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the next day. Enid has set up a GARAGE SALE in front her apartment building. Rebecca arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it? I can't believe you're  selling some of this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Everything must go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, I remember this hat...  this was during your little old lady  phase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trendy young HIPSTER happens along and looks through th clothes, then to the table where he picks up a ridiculous looking stuffed animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noticing price tag) Wait, it says five dollars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a mistake -- I decided  not to sell it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HIPSTER looks around a little more and then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that all about? I thought  everything must go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah right, like I'm gonna let  some asshole with a goatee own Goofy  Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple is browsing. The GIRL, a severely skinny, CLUBHO TYPE in platform shoes looks at the clothes; the BOY, a l haired SKATEBOARDER, goes through her records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is this dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, you're selling that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) That's five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy -- it should be like  two dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wearing that dress the day I  lost my virginity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why do I care about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you even want it? It would  look stupid on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid turns to the boy - he's holding some records and a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that stuff back, it's not for  sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Some fuckin' joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stomp off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now are you going to get a regular  job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defeated, quiet) Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it makes you feel any better, I  don't think you could've gotten more  than ten bucks for all this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes later. Most of the stuff is gone. Enid pac up one last box to carry inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to do something tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, it's Seymour's birthday... (suddenly) Shit! What time is it?  I have to go  to the store! I was going to make  him a cake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miffed, sighs) Well, are we still going shopping  tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess... call me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads toward the stairs with the box. Rebecca watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when can you make a cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid presents Seymour with a HOSTESS CUPCAKE with a singl lit candle in the center. The lights are off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can open your eyes now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... uh, thanks a lot Enid... I  really appreciate it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Doofus... blow it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans forward and blows out the candle, then abruptly  straightens up and holds the small of his back in pain. E turns the lights back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrrghhh! Ah Jeez... Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my stupid back. I'll be  all right in a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices him adjust something under his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... uh... It's just this elastic  thing I have to wear for lumbar  support...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, like a girdle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe now you understand why I can't  get a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you're not the only one.   Everybody I know has totally fucked  up problems... It seems like only  stupid people have good  relationships...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically cheering  her on) That's the spirit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I'm eighteen years old and  I've never even had a real, steady  boyfriend for more than like two  weeks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to think that even if I  did get a girlfriend it really  wouldn't change anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's not like it makes all  your problems go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then again, that's easy for me to  say, since I'll never even get a  date. I'm sure you have hundreds of  guys who are interested in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I've got a total crush on  this one guy right now, but it's a  really fucked-up situation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wait, you met him... remember  that guy Josh? I'm like practically  obsessed with him, but I can't do  anything about it because Becky would  freak out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, it's way too  complicated... (pause) Did you have problems like this when  you were my age - where you're totally  confused all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't even dignify that with a  response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and looks through his shelves for a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his records) I wonder if you really like all these  old records or if you only like the  fact that nobody else likes them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sore subject) Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Seymour ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the machine get it. I have no  desire to talk to anyone who would  be calling me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After several more RINGS the machine picks up and we hear Seymour's message. After the BEEP there's a long fumbling pause...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it... it's my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... HI!  Uh... I'm calling for...  um... you placed an ad in the Weekly  over a month ago and... well, I'm  the redhead in the yellow dress...  at least I think I am... I saw the  ad when you first placed it but I  was in this relationship at the time  so I cut it out, and now I'm not in  the relationship anymore... (giggles) God, this is really confusing...  anyway, if you still want to talk to  me I can be reached at KL5-2603,  that's my work number and my name is  Dana... um... BYE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! (feigning ignorance) What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just somebody's idea of a joke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That didn't sound like a joke to  me... what, did you write a personal  ad or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still confused) Uh yeah. A long time ago... she called  before once... it's just somebody  trying to humiliate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour! I promise you that wasn't a  joke -- you have to call her back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be so sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... I'm an expert-about stuff  like this -- she was totally for  real!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid enters - a light is on in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumpkin? Could you come in here for  a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks slowly to the kitchen - a suspenseful moment. S sees, first, her Dad (wearing an apron) and then, a haunt familiar MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumpkin, do you remember Maxine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (to Dad) Look, I'm kind of tired - I think  I'll go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made spaghetti. Do you want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I really have to get up early for  class tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really quite something to see  you all grown up like this, Enid. (no response from  Enid) I'd love to hear about what you're  doing. I can't help but feel that I  had some small part in how you turned  out... (another silent pause) What are you studying? You were always  such a smart little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking a remedial high school  art class for fuck-ups and retards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toothy, zit-covered 14-YEAR-OLD BOY poses with a very p made sculpture. A flash goes off and he jumps slightly,  sending pieces of his sculpture flying. It's Roberta, taking photos. She moves on to Enid, in fro of her big painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile, Enid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid ad-libs a weird expression as... the flash goes off. Roberta now turns to address the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss you people... I  feel that we've all done a lot of  growing this summer. I hope that  each of you feels as though you'll  be taking away something from this  experience; I know I certainly will  be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long "poignant" pause as she smiles admiringly at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, the art show is this  Saturday at seven-thirty sharp. Try  to get there at least 15 minutes  early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students get their things together and file out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid, can I talk to you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry - it's nothing bad. I  was just wondering what your plans  were for next year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really sure - working, I  guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know this is really short  notice, but I got a call from a very  close friend at the Academy of Art &  Design and she tells me that I'm  allowed to place one student from  your graduating class in a one year  scholarship program... and, well, I  hope you don't mind, Enid, but I  took the liberty of submitting your  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives her a booklet and an application form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I know it includes housing  and meals and everything... it is  really quite an offer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... Would I have to take  classes and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me know as soon as you can, Enid.  This could be a great thing for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Rebecca are in a Crate & Barrel-type store housewares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think one of us should fuck Josh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you're really obsessed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not -- I just think it'd be  funny to see what he'd do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we decided that Josh was  way too cool to be interested in  sex, and that he's the only decent  person left in the world and we would  never want to bring him down to our  level and all that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but maybe one of us should at  least try...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter what happened it would be  a big disaster... Let's just try and  keep everything the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca spots some particularly fetching dishware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we have to get these...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't afford stuff like this right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of waiting - we need to  start getting stuff if we're ever  going to move. (pause, sees towels) Aren't these the greatest towels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you care about this kind of  stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want nice stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't imagine spending money on  towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to. I'll pay for all  the stuff right now and you can pay  me back when you finally get a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still want to go to that thing  tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy's band is playing tonight...  Alien Autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... maybe... Seymour's going  on his big date tonight and I kind  of want to be around when he calls,  so I can hear how bad it went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I'm so sick of Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour is just finishing the dinner DANA has cooked for  them at her place. Dana is an attractive redhead, about 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was great - jeez, thanks again  for cooking all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I love to cook. I guess most women  wouldn't invite a man over on the  first date, but I believe you should  trust your instincts. When I talked  to you on the phone you just seemed  so... I don't know... harmless. Ready  for ice cream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana heads for the kitchen. Seymour gets up to relieve hi backache. He walks over to a framed photo on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are... it's mocha mint from  Lickety Splits. Oh, isn't that  photograph just heart-rending?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... where is this? Bosnia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Bosnia? I forget... (pause) It's so sad, the tragedy of an entire  country eloquently captured in the  face of one little boy. (pause) A Soul/Funk song starts up on the  radio that catches her attention.  She goes over and turns it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I just love this song! Isn't it  great? Doesn't it make you want to  dance? C'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, that's okay - I don't dance,  heh, heh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, anyone can dance.   Here, just follow me... watch my  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drags him around. He's still holding his ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Seymour, it's all in your mind.  Just loosen up and feel the music!  Here, put down your bowl of ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his ice cream and puts it on a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Hey, it's nearly nine already - we're  gonna have to leave now if we're  going to make that movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all right... Party-pooper! Just  let me put a few things away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shuts off the stereo as he sits and eats his ice crea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so excited to see this film -  Dustoffvarnya is such a brilliant  director! Did you see his last film,  The Flower That Drank The Moon? It  was simply glorious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no. I missed that one. But what  do I know? I like Laurel and Hardy  movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I never really cared for  those. Why does the fat one always  have to be so mean to the skinny  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 9:30 PM. Enid is drawing in her sketchbook. She look impatiently at the phone. Time passes - it's 11 PM. She c stand it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour picks up the phone. Dana is in the background get some ice in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, it's me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost whispering) Actually, it's kind of still  happening... she's over here right  now... I think everything's going  pretty well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You're kidding me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so I better go -- it's not  really the best time to talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are you going to like have sex  with her on your first date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Enid... I'll talk to you  later... bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Enid is stunned... Now what? She calls Rebec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is sitting on the couch in her pajamas when the p RINGS. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still want to do something  tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to Seymour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still shocked by  this) I can't believe it - he actually  scored!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How repulsive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So should I come over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm just about to go out  with some friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some people from work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well, you said you were busy...  look, I'd better get going... I'll  call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca hangs up. Clearly, she's not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid stands outside Josh's door. A tentative pause; then knocks. Josh opens the door, stunned. Enid is wearing an  uncharacteristically "sexy" outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes in and looks around nervously... the note (Tiffa & Amber) is tacked to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the one who left that note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Enid sits down on futon/sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up half-finished beer and drinks self-consciousl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I'm totally  confused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh doesn't respond - there's another awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits, tentatively. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean "why"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to get me wasted so  you can take advantage of my womanly  charms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yeah, right"... well why not?  What's  so wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you hate me so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I say I hated you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never once said anything even  remotely nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make me nervous! I always feel  like you're going out of your way to  make me feel uncomfortable so you  can laugh at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just the way I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my stupid way of getting  attention! God, I practically love  you, Josh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned pause, then she bravely leans forward and kisses  him.  He kisses back but she is clearly the aggressor...  they get more and more into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, post-coital on the now unfolded futon... Enid lies her back, Josh is face-down on top of her with his head t the side. Enid has a blank, disillusioned stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now he's romantic  and sappy) You must have known all along how I --  you know -- how I felt about you --  it must be totally obvious...  God...  I always used to dream about this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring ahead) Why do you have that stupid poster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the next morning. Josh is asleep. Enid, fully awake dressed, sits on the bed looking at him, thoroughly  disillusioned. She pulls out a record from his collection and grimaces. She opens a closet door and finds an electr guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waking up, groggy,  happily surprised) Oh, hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do all guys have to play stupid  guitars? It's so typical... Either  they're into cars or guns or sports  or guitars... it's so obvious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep... I should get  going; I feel really weird...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to go get breakfast  somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we should... Look, you  have to totally promise me you won't  tell Becky about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you do, I'll kill you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take my word for it... if she  ever finds out about this I'll never  hear the end of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca is dressed in her best apartment-hunting outfit. sits on her bed, dialing the phone with the FREE WEEKLY o on her lap. She circles something with her pen while the  phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, bitch -- where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid lies perfectly still on her bed, staring at the ceil while the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour sits alone eating lunch. We see Enid approach  stealthily from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very startled) YAAA!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been? I've been looking  all over for you... I've been  wandering the streets day and night  trying to find you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually Joe told me you were  here... so how come you never call  me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I'm sorry... I-I've been  really busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll bet! So, how's it going  with what's-her-name? Dana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he looks nervously  at his watch) Oh... pretty well, surprisingly...  you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what kind of stuff do you guys  do together? Is she into old records  and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of... she doesn't dislike any  of that stuff... she's trying,  anyway... actually, we're supposed  to go antique shopping for her  apartment this afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not convinced) Sounds good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour looks again at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really should get together sometime  soon... I-I'll definitely call you  this week --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are you trying to get rid of  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no, it's just that I should  get going in a few minutes, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you even going to ask me how  I'm doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I'm sorry... uh so... uh... how --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... okay, I guess... (pause) I fucked that guy Josh finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so... is he your boyfriend now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... I dunno... He wants to be,  of course. I'm weighing several offers  at the present time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Dana enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour?... uh... hello... I guess  I'm a little early...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana! Hi! (pause as the gears  whirl) Uh, Dana... this is Enid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great to finally meet you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana sits next to Seymour, facing Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back and  forth between Enid  and Seymour) How do you two know each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised he hasn't mentioned me  we're old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're very close... In fact, I  was standing right next to Seymour  the first time you called. If not  for me, he would have never called  you back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour begins to stammer some kind of response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (phony) Oops! Look at the time!  I've got to  run! I'll stop by to see you some  time, Seymour... (then to Dana) It was really great to meet you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is in her room getting dressed. Dad enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some good news for you,  Pumpkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sigh) What is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still looking for a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Maxine thinks she can get you  a sales job at Computer Station.   Normally you have to have references  and at least two years of experience,  but she thinks she can convince them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to forget it - I don't need  her help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homemade banner reads: "HIGH SCHOOL ART SHOW - BROTHERH AND COMMUNITY: ART AS DIALOGUE." Along one wall is all th work from Roberta's class: a collection of eccentric abst bric-a-brac and Enid's large painting. The painting has d a small crowd. We see a chain of events beginning with th PARENTS talking to a matronly DIRECTOR/CURATOR who in tur seeks out Roberta (wearing make-up and fancy-ish clothes the first time).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you're simply going to  have to take that painting down.   Several of the parents have  complained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you leave me no other choice  than to remove it myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She marches towards it. Roberta runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should give the artist a  chance to talk to the parents about  her intentions with this piece...   We should be promoting discussion as  a solution, not censorship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta sees Margaret and grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, have you seen Enid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret shrugs "no." ROBERTA looks through the crowd. A  college-age news-hack-type with a FREE WEEKLY T-SHIRT sna a photo of the DIRECTOR removing Enid's painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid, dressed as though for a glamorous date, stands knoc on Seymour's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... uh, hi... What's up?

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEYMOUR'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Enid worms her way past his unwelcoming stance. Seymour i wearing designer stone-washed denim jeans that look ridic on him. Joe can be seen in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to this stupid art show  and I want you to be my date...   There's something I have to show  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know. I don't really  think I should...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you should. C'mon, I'm  already a million hours late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I better not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Well forget the art show... let's do  something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I wish I could, Enid, but I  really can't right now... I -- it's  just that I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well when can we do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, well, you know, Dana  just got out of a really bad  relationship and I don't want to  give her the wrong idea... you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking by with his  sandwich) Don't mind me, I'll just be in my  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get those pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh... they were a present from  Dana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you like them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know... what do I know  about clothes... I've never been the  most fashionable guy -- it's nice to  have someone do all the work for  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So that's it? You don't ever want to  see me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course I do... It's just that  right now I need to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her problem anyway?  Did she  actually tell you you couldn't see  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... not exactly... she just  doesn't understand how I would know  somebody like you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she mean by that - "somebody  like me"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just someone so young...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have done something to make  her think you like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean you don't like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks him in the eye) So, do you like me, Seymour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In whatever way you think I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not sure what to  say; long pause) I don't know... I'm sorry, but Dana's  a very jealous person. I just don't  want to screw that up right now...  I'm sure she'll dump me soon and we  can go back to being friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand how I  really feel about you, Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Nothing. Don't worry, I won't bother  you any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT of Enid as she walks home alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Rebecca walk down the street. Both wear landlo friendly J. Crew outfits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we? This is a weird  neighborhood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a totally normal, average  neighborhood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just mean it's weird to me...   I've never been anywhere near here  in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh says this is a really good  neighborhood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? When did you see Josh?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came into work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! God, don't act so  jealous I only talked to him for two  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along in conspicuous silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven fifty-three... do you  see it? (looks around) That must be it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without enthusiasm) Great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! It looks totally normal...  what's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said "great"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I can tell you really love  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what am I supposed to say? "I  can't wait to live in some depressing  shit-hole in the middle of nowhere"?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with every  single place we look at! Why don't  you just come right out and tell me  you don't want to move in with me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you'll freak out and act  like a total psycho about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few passersby stop to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the psycho! You haven't been  able to deal with anything since  high school ended!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one who's still living  out some stupid seventh-grade fantasy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she walks away  giving her the finger) FUCK YOU! Have fun living with your  dad for the rest of your life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid is on her bed, crying. Her jacket and shoes are stre about the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God FUCK YOU TOO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see her Dad standing outside her bedroom. As he enters tries to make enough noise so that she notices him before she really embarrasses herself. She stops crying and pret to be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumpkin? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her back to him,  doesn't move) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad sits next to her on the bed and puts his hand on her  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's something wrong I wish  you'd tell me about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid pulls away from him and sits up on the opposite side the bed, facing away from him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing -- it's just some  hormonal thing... don't worry about  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some important news to tell  you, but it can wait till later if  you're not feeling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking slowly and  methodically) Well... as you know, Maxine and I  have been seeing a lot of each other,  and we decided it might be a good  idea for all of us if she came back  here to live at the end of the Summer,  just so we can all get to know each  other and to make sure this is what  we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid maintains a poker face for several long seconds befo she bursts into tears, utterly defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid, determined, walks down the empty halls. She goes in a room marked "Art Class".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta is in there with a bearded EX-HIPPY COLLEAGUE. They're covering a STUDENT in plaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi I brought over my application for  the art academy... I hope it's not  too late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roberta, absorbed in her plastering, glances at Enid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, realizing who it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid! I'm so sorry about what  happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole business with the art show  and the newspaper -- it's absolutely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Principal Jaffee call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't check my messages...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness... well, the whole  thing is just ridiculous, and as  soon as the school board is back in  session next Fall I'm going to do  everything I can to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they're forcing me to give you  a non-passing grade in the class  because of what happened at the  exhibition... but don't worry -- I'm  sure I'll be able to get you your  diploma in the Fall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, overwhelmed) But... can I still get that  scholarship to the Art Academy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Enid - you have to be an  official high school graduate before  I can nominate you.  I had to give  it to someone else...  But I'm sure  next year I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLASTER-COVERED STUDENT makes an uncomfortable moanin noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered, to Roberta) Hey, can you help me out over here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid walks the streets - it's dark out now. She goes by t Cafe - it's CLOSED FOR REMODELING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues walking until she's across the street from  Norman's bus stop. She sees him there, as always. Suddenl a BUS, well-lit from the inside and completely empty, pul up to the stop and Norman gets on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock on the door - Seymour shuffles out in T-shirt, pa and goofy slippers. He looks through the peephole and see Enid. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you at least let me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... sure... come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Look, I just need somebody to be  nice to me for five minutes and then  I'll leave you alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid goes to look for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I think there's some root  beer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns from the kitchen with a giant bottle of champ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Dana's - I'm supposed to be  saving it for our two-month  anniversary. You better not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she starts opening) FUCK DANA. I'm sick of Dana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens it and drinks straight from the bottle. Seymour look says: "Oh well, I'm fucked, I give up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid & Seymour sit on the bed listening to old record drinking out of the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a bigger place - this is  like a little kid's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never move - I've got too  much stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid notices an extremely ugly modern sculpture in the co She goes over and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana bought it when we went antique  shopping. She said it didn't go with  her stuff, so she gave it to me...  she thought it fit in better with my  "old time thingamajigs."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, how can you stand her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour takes another slug off the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, she's going to kill me... this  bottle is half-empty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great! "Half-empty" - that's  what I like about you, Seymour, you're  a natural pessimist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you expect the worst, you're never  disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You're  disappointed every minute of your  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just being realistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you're not like every other  stupid guy in the world - all they  care about are guitars and sports...  they're all such fags!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come in all that time I was trying  to get you a date, you never asked  me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a beautiful young girl... I  can't imagine you would ever have  had any interest in me, except as an  amusingly cranky eccentric curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but still... it's kind of  insulting for a girl to be ignored  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... of course I... why wouldn't  I want to go out with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I always feel like  everybody secretly hates me. I'm  just paranoid I guess. I mean, you  like me don't you? We're good friends,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemplative pause) ...Maybe I should just move in here  with you... I could do all the cooking  and dust your record collection and  stuff until I get a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... and Dana... (says her name with  whiny, disdainful  voice) You were a lot more fun before you  met Dana. You've been acting way too  normal lately... you're a bitter,  twisted, fucked-up guy, Seymour,  that's why I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more drunk than before) Yeah, well I like you too...

dialogues.speaker: TEN MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: The bottle is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what my number one fantasy  used to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to think about one day not  telling anybody and just taking off  and going to some random place...   Do you ever think about stuff like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I probably used to when I  was your age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have to be some totally  average day when nobody was expecting  it, and I'd just disappear and they'd  never see me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a healthy way to deal  with your problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what we should do? Let's go  get in your car right now and just  take off! We could just drive away  and find some new place and start a  whole new life... fuck everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm in any condition  to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive, then -- we'll go out in  a blaze of glory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where would we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? Let's just go... what's  stopping us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious! I'm just so sick of  everybody! Why can't I just do  whatever I want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Seymour?  Don't you like me? Be a man for once  in your life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him passionately. He's shocked but kisses back This escalates, leading to the sex act, shown with mercif brevity. WE SEE Enid & Seymour, post-coital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Dana's going to kill you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Do you really want us to drive  away somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Maybe... no... I dunno...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... forget it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassingly sappy) I-I never expected anything like  this to happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... me neither...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must know I always... did you  really mean all that about moving in  with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking out loud... (doesn't want to hurt  his feelings) I mean, you've got this whole thing  with Dana -- I'm not going to let  you fuck that up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh... I really need to get some  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enid turns her back to him. We see from REVERSE ANGLE tha she's only pretending to be asleep. She looks troubled, a though she's just made a big mistake. Seymour puts his ar around her. It's the only time we've seen him look relaxe and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her arm and goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour wakes up. Enid is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana is on the phone. A lantern-jawed male COLLEAGUE list in, his head pressed up against hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's a thirty-year fixed at five and- a-half...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seymour nervously enters her "workspace". Dana is pleasan surprised - she stops her conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering receiver) Seymour! Hello! What are you doing  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- please - don't let me interrupt  finish your phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost done. (she continues into  phone) Hi. Yeah... no, it's excluded.   They've already paid the earnest  money... well, let them bring it up  if they notice it at the final walk  through. Right, great, sounds good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and high-fives her colleague. They bear-hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great job! I'm proud of ya! Well,  I'll check you guys later. I'm gonna  go start the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colleague leaves; Dana turns to Seymour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... so, what brings you down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
